Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2008 09:07PM jezza wrote: Hey I just posted and lost it so hope this doesn't appear twice!  I had a Jan. mastectomy but it was 17 years ago this coming January. The girls here are right..it is not that painful. I had a dressing gown or robe with pockets either side. I was able to put the drains in there which hid them from my kids cos the children were small then and would have found them a bit confronting. I am in Australia and you usually have to stay in hospital until the drains come out so they can keep an eye on you. I have saline implants and I'm happy with the result. This waiting time is the worst but I'm sure it will go well for you all.You can also send private messages to each other if you want through this site. Hugs jezza

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 07:06PM jezza wrote: A friend's DH was transferred to America for work and they were visiting the new boss and wife who had a young baby. My friend fussed over the baby and said he was gorgeous and put out her arms and asked if she could "nurse" him.The lady looked a little taken aback. In Aust. that means to hold a baby and cuddle him. Apparently in America (or at least in that part of America) it means to breastfeed. My friend was mortified when she was told later that she had asked to breastfeed her bosses son! Great thread sheli even if its gotten a little off track...I, too justhad to take a look! jezza
Posts.Title: Just Need to Wank sbelizabeth autism_mom

Posts.Content: May 10, 2012 12:10PM jezza wrote: Mortified....am on the internet at work ...at lunchtime so wasn't worried when the boss came to ask me something. He discussed a work matter and then I noticed he was looking at the screen and not me. When he walked off I noticed that the heading "JUST NEEDED TO WANK" was right up the top of the page and yes...it does mean "to pleasure yourself in Australia"! I'm going to put my head down and do some serious work for the rest of the day.........  jezza
Posts.Title: Just Need to Wank sbelizabeth autism_mom

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 12:43AM jezza wrote: I have a small glass of white while I'm cooking dinner and at least 1, ocassionally 2 glasses of red with  dinner almost every night. Sometimes I have an alcohol free day. I love cooking but really don't enjoy it as much if I'm not having a sip every now and then! For the first 6 months after dx I was pretty worried about everything I ate or drank . After that I just went back to normal and have enjoyed over 18 years of cooking, entertaining and yes drinking more or less what I like!  jezza
Posts.Title: I will have a Glass of Red Wine please!! faithfulheart faithfulheart

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 09:35PM jezza wrote: Oh Mary ..Waiting is the WORST time and shouldn't be prolonged like this. Sometimes it just takes a call from your doctor to get them. I had to wait over a long weekend and that was bad enough. The holdup will have nothing to do with how good/bad the results are. Its just like in any job...some ppl are quicker and more effecient in getting the job done and sending off results. I would have asked the Dr if he could get them ASAP and let you know though.BC teaches us to be a bit pushy. Wishing for good results for you. Hugs jezza

I would have liked to have had the opportunity to have had that mammogram when I had asked. For peace of mind I would ask for a proper examination. jezza

Posts.Title: painful left breast frilly jezza

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 05:35PM jezza wrote: I was dx in 1992. Even when you get your mum's records it will be hard to compare her dx with your own although I would certainly agree that you should get a copy. Back then they didn't do the tests they do now. Ppl often ask me if I am ER+ or - PR+ or- HER+ and I just don't know.They certainly did have chemo back then. Your mum would probably only have been offered it if her tumour was over over 1cm or seemed aggressive or if she had positive nodes. From what you say about your mum following Dr's orders I'm sure she wouldn't have refused it if it had been suggested. Unfortunately it is impossible to say whether she would have had a recurrence if she had had chemo. I hope she is going OK. jezza

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 01:07AM jezza wrote: Trina......I had the same after a bone scan. Pam got mine in one. I had slipped on our stairs a few months earlier..carpeted stairs... I winded myself and was a bit sore for a couple of days but I had forgotten about it. When they asked me if I had had a fall..I thought they meant recently and said no. After an anxious wait and more xrays..and more waiting they said it was a healed cracked rib! I guess it happened on the stairs..its hard to remember something minor that happened a while ago... Hugs...any more suggestions...I know I totally freaked out. jezza

Posts.Title: in the years after TC treatment limegreen hrf

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 08:05PM - edited Aug 7, 2009 08:06PM by jezza I am 17 and a half years out...no recurrence....but I didn't do chemo. Two friends of mine were dx about 6 months after me. They are coming up to their 17 year mark..both did chemo and both are fine. Most ppl who have lived long and healthy lives after diagnosis don't belong to boards like these.It is mostly made up of newly dx ppl and those who have had recurrences. When ppl have finished chemo and treatment they often move on...thats why this site...although fantastic does not give a very accurate picture of long term survival. hugs jezza

Posts.Title: Biopsy is over luvz2bmama Bren-2007

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 06:48PM jezza wrote: Hi Lindy A few of the girls on our Australian BC forum have had the onco type test. You have to send samples to America for it and it is expensive (about $5000 I think from memory) and of course not covered by medicare etc...and not every onc here likes the test. My BS said I was 50/50 as to whether chemo would benefit me and I decided to have a prophylactic mastectomy. I went for a 2nd opinion about 6 or 7 months later (like you...reading and worrying) and the onc said I should def. had had chemo but it was too late now! Anyway its 19 years since my diagnosis and I've had no recurrence so I guess I made the right decision. Its very hard to compare cancers and treatments so you are doing exactly the right thing by going to another onc with all your info. I wish you all the best.  jezza
